_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Organic Chemical Manufacturing

_accidents.CI_OtherType: Re-trained area employees and reviewed lockout plan
Additional management, improve management of change-personnel and operational discipline

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Chemours Memphis Plant (The Chemours Company FC, LLC) is located north of Memphis in the unincorporated Lucy-Woodstock area of Shelby County near the intersection of Hwy 51 and Fite Road.  The facilities began operation in 1952 and has operated safely within the community for over 60 years.



We manufacture Hydrogen Cyanide, a basic building block chemical for the manufacture of acrylics products (manufactured by another company) and Solid Cyanides, also produced on our site for use in the mining and metallurgical industries.  We also produce a family of Aminonitrile Intermediates used to make reaction initiators.  Since the last RMP update, we divested the Oxone(TM) Business through sale to the Lanxess Corporation and have removed the process from this Risk Management Plan. 



The Chemours Memphis Plant is committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  This document provides a brief overview of our comprehensive risk management activities.



1. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Our policy is that all accidental releases to the environment can be prevented.   Therefore, our goal is to not have a release that negatively impacts the public, environment, or plant personnel.  We work closely with local off-site emergency responders to ensure that in the unlikely event a spill or release goes beyond our fence line, we are all prepared to respond.



2. REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



Of the materials we handle, the following chemicals meet the Risk Management Plan threshold for assessment and reporting.   EPA has identified these materials as having potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:



Toxics:    Ammonia (NH3)

     Hydrocyanic Acid (HCN)

Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)



Flammables:    Hydrogen

 



3. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



At Chemours we take safet

y, health, and the environment very seriously.  We have designed several levels of safety into our operations and practices so that multiple failures must happen for a release to occur.  Since each one of our layers of defense is very reliable, the probability of a release that spreads beyond our plant boundary is very small.  



Listed below are some examples of the things we do to prevent releases and reduce the impact of releases that do occur: 



(a) Plant equipment is designed carefully, to minimize the probability of a major leak or spill.



(b) All unusual operations, and small leaks or spills are investigated to prevent recurrence.



(c) Safety controls such as instrumentation, warning alarms, monitoring equipment, and automatic shutdown systems are installed.



(d)Thorough routine audits of the process are conducted.



(e) Regular equipment inspections and maintenance insure proper operations.



(f) Training and testing of operators and mechanics ensures they follow safe operating procedures.



4. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Under the RMP, EPA requires owners or operators to report all accidental releases that resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, or property or environmental damage.  For the Chemours Memphis Site, there were two incidents involving exposures to regulated material that met the five-year accident history reporting criteria.



5. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The Chemours Memphis Site has developed a comprehensive Emergency Action Plan that helps us protect the health of the public and our employees and prevent harm to the environment.   The plan establishes the emergency response organization, the training and preparation requirements, the equipment and facilities used for response, and procedures utilized during response.



 

The overall site Emergency Action Plan begins with a brief description of the purpose and primary objecti

ves for the plan.   This includes: 



(a) Prevent injuries - both on and off-plant



(b) Minimize property damage



(c) Minimize interruptions to the continuity of operations

         

(d) Maintain security of company property

         

(e) Ensure that the site and community are prepared to effectively deal with an incident that has the potential to significantly impact them

         

(f) Maintain good public relations

         

An Emergency is defined as any incident occurring on or off the plant that may affect the safety of off-plant neighbors, plant personnel or operations, to the extent that coordination of plant personnel is required through channels other than those normally used.  The content of the plan applies to the following typical types of emergency conditions that might occur at this site: fuming condition and/or hazardous chemical release, fires and explosions, confined space rescues, spills beyond the control of a process area, personal medical emergencies, potential terrorist activities (post event), severe weather conditions and natural disasters.  A higher level of emergency, called a Plant Wide Emergency, is declared: whenever there is risk off site; when more than one operating area on site is affected; or when additional resources are needed to respond to the incident.



Each RMP covered process, operating area and normally occupied building on the site maintains a portion of the Emergency Action Plan specific to their operations or facilities.



Informing the Public and Local Emergency Response: 



There are four ways the public is notified whenever an Emergency occurs that may potentially impact them.  First, our procedures require the site Emergency Response Team to notify the Shelby County Office of Preparedness by telephone during the emergency.   Second, our site has implemented a Community Communication System whereby individuals can call to hear a voice message on the status of an incident.   Third, our facility has an on-site notifi

cation system that is also audible in the immediate vicinity of the local community that will indicate an emergency condition is occurring.   Fourth, based on incident information and conditions, the Incident Commander recommends community alert level to the Shelby County Office of Preparedness.



 

First Aid and Medical Treatment: 



Plant supervisors and selected members of the Emergency Response team are designated and trained annually to provide first aid coverage when Medical personnel are not on site.   The person providing first aid is also responsible to take whatever action is necessary for prompt transportation of injured or ill personnel to the nearest hospital.  Site Safety, Health, and Environmental Standards for Off-Plant Medical Treatment and Incident Classification, Investigation and Reporting are the written documents that describe these procedures.



Procedures for Handling Accidental Release of a Regulated Substance:



Hazardous materials emergencies may result from a spill or uncontrolled release of one or more plant materials.  Response to these incidents may require the services of the plant fire brigade or members of Chemours' Integrated Emergency Response Team.   All responses must comply with 29 CFR 1910.120 (q) - Hazardous Waste Operation and Emergency Response.



The Incident Commander will, upon completion of the initial assessment, request the assistance of either the shift fire brigade or Integrated Emergency Response Team members.  In some situations, both organizations may be required to assist in handling the hazardous materials incident.  Additional resources may be obtained by requesting assistance from the Shelby County Fire Department.



The Memphis Site Fire Brigade Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) describes the detailed response steps the site will take in the event of a hazardous material emergency.



The following equipment is maintained on site to assist in responding to the location of the hazardous materials rele

ases:



(a) Industrial Foam Attack Engine 

(b) Aerial Ladder Rescue Truck with Water Tower capability

(c) Site Rescue / Hazmat Equipment Truck 



Coordination with Community Emergency Response Organizations:



Our site has reviewed and coordinated our Emergency Response Plan with local agencies and the Local Emergency Planning Committee.   Members of local fire department(s) and emergency response services have been to our site and participated in joint training with our emergency response employees.



6. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The following are improvements that we are planning to implement at the facility to help prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:



(a) Continued improvement of safety practices and systems

(b) Significant upgrades to product management to provide inherently safer storage and emergency control
